audio_caption: The audio begins with soothing music, evoking a sentimental mood with its string instruments. A male speaker then introduces himself as Jonathan Kingston, a photographer for the National Geographic Image Collection, describing his work for the magazine and its expeditions arm. He explains the image collection as an in-house agency representing photographers who've worked for the magazine, finding assignments and managing their stock archive. He mentions his father is a very famous guy.

A single male speaker enthusiastically recounts that his father, an organic chemist who emigrated from London and was educated at Cambridge and MIT, helped invent a drug called Taxol, used for breast and ovarian cancer. The speaker then mentions his mother, an analytical chemist, helped invent the magenta dye used in Polaroids, followed by humorously saying, "so you know, obviously there are no expectations in my family of being a scientist".

The audio clip begins with a male speaker reflecting on his less-than-stellar academic performance, especially in high school. He then shifts to the topic of how he discovered photography, mentioning a vocational program with a "great photo teacher". He shares that he learned about "focal lengths and lenses" and other photography-related concepts, and participated in contests, where he was frequently successful. The audio ends with a single word, "Sweet".

The audio clip begins with a male speaker sharing an anecdote. He describes returning home from high school and announcing to his father his desire to become a professional photographer. He then describes his father, complete with a bowtie and British accent, advising him against it. The speaker recounts a back and forth that eventually leads to his father's conditional blessing, advising him to get a degree in anything but photography to have other skills to fall back on. The male speaker's voice is conversational, storytelling.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker stating, "And I get it, I'm a new dad," then mentions having a "10-month-old daughter at home." He then discusses the Fine Arc Galleries and their start in "2016 if I remember correctly." His tone is conversational and casual. There are no music or background sounds present.

The audio clip features a single male speaker with a conversational and passionate tone. He describes how the National Geographic image collection contacted him to be part of their galleries, and he recounts the experience of taking the "Heartwave shot". He details the conditions at a specific spot on the island of Molokai, a west-facing white sand beach with a 90-degree turn, where sand washes away during storms, creating a slope.  Here, the waves collide to form explosions of water under the luminous sunset light.

The clip features a single male speaker discussing photography, describing the predictability of the "light's great" conditions, and then noting how the heart wave was something unpredictable, feeling like a "miracle". He then transitions to discussing the "swimming elephant" shot, stating that it's one of his favorites. He mentions the work it took to capture it over two years and discusses its ethereal feel and the special place it holds in his heart.

The clip begins with a male speaker describing his experience as a new graduate of Brooks Institute of Photography in 2002, recalling his first job teaching at a photo school in South India. He explains that one night, he watched an old Jacques Cousteau special on Discovery Channel titled "Andaman Islands Invisible Islands." The male speaker then summarizes the special, stating that Jacques Cousteau talked about elephants brought to the Andaman Islands that would swim between islands, with some islands having female elephants and others having male elephants. When the elephants went into musth, they would swim from one island to another to mate before returning to the island where their caretakers were.

A man speaks in an excited tone, describing seeing a special and instantly picturing a shot of a "swimming elephant." He then describes the Andaman Islands as an Indian naval base and how difficult it is for an American to get there. He explains that, because the elephants are considered government employees, he needed permission from the Ministry of Environment and Forest to film them. He describes taking a train from Udhagamandalam down to Chennai and an airplane to the Andaman Islands. He says that he got upgraded to first class and was thinking about the shot in his head when a flight attendant gave him the Port Blair Times newspaper.

A male speaker begins by describing opening something and reading a headline: "Chief Minister of environment and forests indicted for corruption and jailed." He continues in a dismayed tone, saying he "felt like someone had just punched me in the stomach," realizing "permission was off" and "the shoot was off."

The audio clip begins with a single male speaker, who expresses that he's at the end of his first year in India and only signed a one-year contract. He re-ups his contract and he's not going to name the island, because he doesn't want "a ton of people going out to this island", but there are two elephants living on it. One side of the island was very shallow, while the other had bathymetry that "fell off very steeply from very shallow to very deep".

The audio clip begins with a single male speaker recounting a story about his experiences filming elephants. He describes starting his day on one side of the island and shooting black and white film of an elephant swimming, mentioning they "don't swim for long," then moving to the other side with color film.  He talks about waiting in a boat and being signaled to start filming the "daily bathing ritual" as the elephant swims out. The speaker is calm and narrative.

The audio begins with a male speaker describing a photographic experience, detailing how he took 36 photos, but only one turned out well. He recounts that in the other shots, the elephant appeared with "one leg" or missing various body parts.  He notes the successful shot captured everything perfectly, adding that the elephant "only swam for five or ten minutes" before leaving. Then he shares a detail about the photograph's background by telling the "story of that shot."  Subsequently, the speaker states he heard many stories from India about "mahouts."

The audio clip begins with a male speaker recounting a story about mahouts and elephants, noting that it's a recurring event in elephant camps, where drunken mahouts are gently carried back to their huts by their elephants. He then transitions to discussing his photography, stating that, while capturing a story through photography, nothing else exists around him, only that moment, that story, that joy. He describes the feeling of pressing the shutter, experiencing a tingle up his arm and into his brain, feeling on fire. The speaker further quotes a friend saying, "celebrate what's right with the world," emphasizing the importance of focusing on the good amidst negativity, and choosing to celebrate the positive aspects of the world as much as possible.  A light, ambient musical piece plays during the speech, complementing the reflective and hopeful tone of the speaker.
